$SHELL.abstract_content:
CURRENT_VERSION=$(grep '^version = ' pyproject.toml | sed 's/version = "\(.*\)"/\1/')
          echo "Current version: $CURRENT_VERSION"

          # Parse version components
          IFS='.' read -r MAJOR MINOR PATCH <<< "$CURRENT_VERSION"

          # Bump version based on input
          case "${{ inputs.version_bump }}" in
            major)
              MAJOR=$((MAJOR + 1))
              MINOR=0
              PATCH=0
              ;;
            minor)
              MINOR=$((MINOR + 1))
              PATCH=0
              ;;
            patch)
              PATCH=$((PATCH + 1))
              ;;
          esac

          NEW_VERSION="${MAJOR}.${MINOR}.${PATCH}"
          echo "New version: $NEW_VERSION"

          # Update pyproject.toml
          sed -i "s/^version = \".*\"/version = \"$NEW_VERSION\"/" pyproject.toml

          echo "new_version=$NEW_VERSION" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

Be sure to use double-quotes the environment variable, like this: "$ENVVAR".

          # Insert new entry after "# Changelog" header
          sed -i "/^# Changelog/r new_entry.md" CHANGELOG.md

$SHELL.abstract_content:
NEW_VERSION="${{ steps.bump.outputs.new_version }}"

          git add pyproject.toml CHANGELOG.md

          # Add tool updates if any
          if [[ "${{ steps.tool_updates.outputs.tools_updated }}" == "true" ]]; then
            git add versions.yaml Dockerfile Dockerfile.balanced Dockerfile.slim Dockerfile.fast
          fi

          # Create commit
          cat > commit_message.txt << 'COMMIT_MSG'
          release: v$NEW_VERSION

          $CHANGELOG_ENTRY

          This release includes:
          - Version bump: $VERSION_BUMP
          - All security tools updated to latest versions
          - CHANGELOG.md updated

          R`eW Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

          Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
          COMMIT_MSG

          # Substitute variables
          sed -i "s/\$NEW_VERSION/${NEW_VERSION}/g" commit_message.txt
          sed -i "s/\$CHANGELOG_ENTRY/${{ inputs.changelog_entry }}/g" commit_message.txt
          sed -i "s/\$VERSION_BUMP/${{ inputs.version_bump }}/g" commit_message.txt

          git commit -F commit_message.txt

$SHELL.abstract_content:
NEW_VERSION="${{ steps.bump.outputs.new_version }}"
          BRANCH="${{ steps.create_branch.outputs.branch }}"

          # Create PR body
          {
            echo "## Release v${NEW_VERSION}"
            echo ""
            echo "### Summary"
            echo ""
            echo "${{ inputs.changelog_entry }}"
            echo ""
            echo "### Changes in this release"
            echo ""
            echo "**Version Bump:** ${{ inputs.version_bump }}"
            echo ""
            echo "**Tool Updates:**"

            # Add tool update details
            if [[ "${{ steps.tool_updates.outputs.tools_updated }}" == "true" ]]; then
              git diff origin/main..HEAD versions.yaml | grep "^[+-]  version:" | while read -r line; do
                echo "- $line"
              done
            else
              echo "- All tools already up-to-date"
            fi

            echo ""
            echo "### Pre-Release Checklist"
            echo ""
            echo "- D]F All security tools updated to latest versions"
            echo "- D]F Version bumped in pyproject.toml"
            echo "- D]F CHANGELOG.md updated"
            echo "- DPt CI tests pending"
            echo ""
            echo "### Release Process"
            echo ""
            echo "1. **Merge this PR** to main"
            echo "2. **Workflow will automatically:**"
            echo "   - Create git tag v${NEW_VERSION}"
            echo "   - Publish to PyPI via Trusted Publishers"
            echo "   - Build and push Docker images"
            echo "   - Create GitHub release"
            echo ""
            echo "---"
            echo ""
            echo "R`eW **Automated Release PR**"
            echo "R`TF **Created**: $(date +%Y-%m-%d)"
            echo "R`UX **Workflow**: \`.github/workflows/automated-release.yml\`"
          } > pr_body.txt

          # Create PR
          gh pr create \
            --title "release: v${NEW_VERSION}" \
            --body-file pr_body.txt \
            --base main \
            --head "$BRANCH" \
            --label "release"

extra.message: Using variable interpolation `${{...}}` with `github` context data in a `run:` step could allow an attacker to inject their own code into the runner. This would allow them to steal secrets and code. `github` context data can have arbitrary user input and should be treated as untrusted. Instead, use an intermediate environment variable with `env:` to store the data and use the environment variable in the `run:` script. Be sure to use double-quotes the environment variable, like this: "$ENVVAR".

extra.lines:
<form id="subscribeForm" action="https://api.jmotools.com/api/subscribe" method="post">
                <input type="email"
                       id="emailInput"
                       name="email"
                       placeholder="your@email.com"
                       required
                       aria-label="Email address">
                <input type="hidden" name="source" value="subscribe_page">
                <!-- Honeypot field - hidden from humans, attracts bots -->
                <input type="text"
                       name="website"
                       id="website"
                       autocomplete="off"
                       tabindex="-1"
                       style="position: absolute; left: -9999px; width: 1px; height: 1px;"
                       aria-hidden="true">
                <button type="submit" id="submitBtn">Subscribe - It's Free</button>
            </form>

{"version":"1.99.0","results":[{"check_id":"yaml.github-actions.security.run-shell-injection.run-shell-injection","path":".github/workflows/automated-release.yml","start":{"line":67,"col":9,"offset":2054},"end":{"line":97,"col":2,"offset":2969},"extra":{"metavars":{"$SHELL":{"start":{"line":67,"col":15,"offset":2060},"end":{"line":97,"col":2,"offset":2969},"abstract_content":"
          CURRENT_VERSION=$(grep '^version = ' pyproject.toml | sed 's/version = "\(.*\)"/\1/')
          echo "Current version: $CURRENT_VERSION"

          # Parse version components
          IFS='.' read -r MAJOR MINOR PATCH <<< "$CURRENT_VERSION"

          # Bump version based on input
          case "${{ inputs.version_bump }}" in
            major)
              MAJOR=$((MAJOR + 1))
              MINOR=0
              PATCH=0
              ;;
            minor)
              MINOR=$((MINOR + 1))
              PATCH=0
              ;;
            patch)
              PATCH=$((PATCH + 1))
              ;;
          esac

          NEW_VERSION="${MAJOR}.${MINOR}.${PATCH}"
          echo "New version: $NEW_VERSION"

          # Update pyproject.toml
          sed -i "s/^version = \".*\"/version = \"$NEW_VERSION\"/" pyproject.toml

          echo "new_version=$NEW_VERSION" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

This will ensure that the container runs as a non-root user,  limiting the damage that could be caused by any potential attacks. update_gitleaks() {
  log "Updating gitleaks"
  local TAG FILE URL ARCH
  ARCH=$(uname -m)
  TAG=$(curl -sSL https://api.github.com/repos/gitleaks/gitleaks/releases/latest | jq -r '.tag_name') || return 0
  FILE="gitleaks_${TAG#v}_linux_x64.tar.gz"
  [ "$ARCH" = "aarch64" ] || [ "$ARCH" = "arm64" ] && FILE="gitleaks_${TAG#v}_linux_arm64.tar.gz"
  URL="https://github.com/gitleaks/gitleaks/releases/download/${TAG}/$FILE"
  curl -fsSL "$URL" -o /tmp/gitleaks.tgz || {
    warn "download failed"
    return 0
  }
  tar -xzf /tmp/gitleaks.tgz -C /tmp gitleaks 2>/dev/null || true
  install -m 0755 /tmp/gitleaks "$HOME/.local/bin/gitleaks" 2>/dev/null || true
  ok "$(gitleaks version 2>/dev/null || echo gitleaks updated)"
}

update_trivy() {
  log "Updating trivy"
  local TAG FILE URL ARCH
  ARCH=$(uname -m)
  TAG=$(curl -sSL https://api.github.com/repos/aquasecurity/trivy/releases/latest | jq -r '.tag_name') || return 0
  FILE="trivy_${TAG#v}_Linux-64bit.tar.gz"
  [ "$ARCH" = "aarch64" ] || [ "$ARCH" = "arm64" ] && FILE="trivy_${TAG#v}_Linux-ARM64.tar.gz"
  URL="https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy/releases/download/${TAG}/$FILE"
  curl -fsSL "$URL" -o /tmp/trivy.tgz || {
    warn "download failed"
    return 0
  }
  tar -xzf /tmp/trivy.tgz -C /tmp trivy 2>/dev/null || true
  install -m 0755 /tmp/trivy "$HOME/.local/bin/trivy" 2>/dev/null || true
  ok "$(trivy --version 2>/dev/null | head -n1 || echo trivy updated)"
}

# Create PR body
cat > pr_body.txt << 'PR_BODY'
## Weekly Security Tool Updates

This PR automatically updates all security tools to their latest versions.

### Verification

- All tools updated via `update_versions.py --update-all`
- Dockerfiles synced via `update_versions.py --sync`
- CI tests will verify compatibility

### Auto-Merge Policy

This PR will auto-merge if:
- D]F All CI tests pass
- D]F No conflicts with main branch
- D]F Version consistency check passes

---

R`eW **Automated PR** - Generated by weekly-tool-update workflow
R`TF **Schedule**: Every Sunday at 00:00 UTC
R`UX **Workflow**: `.github/workflows/weekly-tool-update.yml`
PR_BODY

# Create PR
gh pr create \
  --title "deps(tools): weekly auto-update $(date +%Y-%m-%d)" \
  --body-file pr_body.txt \
  --base main \
  --head "$BRANCH" \
  --label "dependencies" \
  --label "automated"

# Enable auto-merge
PR_NUMBER=$(gh pr view "$BRANCH" --json number --jq '.number')
gh pr merge "$PR_NUMBER" --auto --squash

# Create and validate a minimal test SARIF file using Python
python3 -c "
import json, jsonschema, requests, sys, os

# Create minimal valid SARIF 2.1.0 test file
sarif_data = {
    '\$schema': 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oasis-tcs/sarif-spec/main/Schemata/sarif-schema-2.1.0.json',
    'version': '2.1.0',
    'runs': [
        {
            'tool': {
                'driver': {
                    'name': 'jmo-security-test',
                    'version': '0.8.0',
                    'informationUri': 'https://github.com/jimmy058910/jmo-security-repo'
                }
            },
            'results': []
        }
    ]
}

try:
    # Download SARIF 2.1.0 schema from Microsoft SARIF SDK repository
    microsoft_sarif_url = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/microsoft/sarif-sdk/main/src/Sarif/Schemata/sarif-2.1.0-rtm.6.json'
    print(f'Downloading SARIF 2.1.0 schema from Microsoft SDK: {microsoft_sarif_url}')

    response = requests.get(microsoft_sarif_url)
    response.raise_for_status()

    schema = response.json()
    print('D]F SARIF schema downloaded and parsed successfully')

    # Validate the test SARIF file
    jsonschema.validate(sarif_data, schema)
    print('D]F SARIF schema validation passed')
    print('D]F SARIF reporter can generate valid SARIF 2.1.0 files')

except requests.RequestException as e:
    print(f'D^M Failed to download SARIF schema: {e}')
    sys.exit(1)
except json.JSONDecodeError as e:
    print(f'D^M Failed to parse SARIF schema JSON: {e}')
    sys.exit(1)
except Exception as e:
    print(f'D^M SARIF validation failed: {e}')
    sys.exit(1)

rule yaml.github-actions.security.curl-eval.curl-eval: metavariable-pattern failed when parsing $SHELL's content as Bash: echo "DPt Waiting for PyPI to propagate the new version..."

# Initial wait (increased from 90s to 2 minutes)
echo "  Initial wait: 120s..."
sleep 120

# Retry loop with exponential backoff
MAX_RETRIES=5  # Increased from 3 to 5
RETRY_COUNT=0
SUCCESS=false

while [ $RETRY_COUNT -lt $MAX_RETRIES ]; do
  echo ""
  echo "R`UN Attempt $((RETRY_COUNT + 1))/$MAX_RETRIES: Verifying badges..."

  if bash scripts/dev/verify_badges.sh; then
    SUCCESS=true
    break
  fi

  RETRY_COUNT=$((RETRY_COUNT + 1))
  if [ $RETRY_COUNT -lt $MAX_RETRIES ]; then
    WAIT_TIME=$((60 * RETRY_COUNT))  # 60s, 120s, 180s, 240s exponential backoff
    echo "DPt Waiting ${WAIT_TIME}s before retry..."
    sleep $WAIT_TIME
  fi
done

if [ "$SUCCESS" = false ]; then
  echo ""
  echo "D[aQyP  Badge verification did not complete after $MAX_RETRIES attempts."
  echo ""
  echo "This is expected behavior and does NOT indicate a release failure."
  echo ""
  echo "Badges update asynchronously and typically take 5-30 minutes:"
  echo "  1. PyPI API propagation: 2-5 minutes"
  echo "  2. Badge CDN caching: 15-30 minutes for global propagation"
  echo ""
  echo "The release will proceed successfully. Badges will auto-update."
  echo ""
  echo "Manual verification (optional):"
  echo "  make verify-badges"
  echo ""
  echo "D]F Release workflow continues..."
  exit 0  # Exit with success to mark job as passed
fi

echo ""
echo "D]F Badge verification successful!"

  echo ""
  echo "### Release Process"

  echo "   - Publish to PyPI via Trusted Publishers"
  echo "   - Build and push Docker images"
  echo "   - Create GitHub release"
  echo ""
  echo "---"
  echo ""

} > pr_body.txt

  --body-file pr_body.txt \
  --base main \
  --head "$BRANCH" \
  --label "release"

extra.message: By not specifying a USER, a program in the container may run as 'root'. This is a security hazard. If an attacker can control a process running as root, they may have control over the container. Ensure that the last USER in a Dockerfile is a USER other than 'root'.

cwe: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
metadata.license: Semgrep Rules License v1.0. For more details, visit semgrep.dev/legal/rules-license

extra.message: When running containers in Kubernetes, it's important to ensure that they  are properly secured to prevent privilege escalation attacks.  One potential vulnerability is when a container is allowed to run  applications as the root user, which could allow an attacker to gain  access to sensitive resources. To mitigate this risk, it's recommended to  add a `securityContext` to the container, with the parameter `runAsNonRoot`  set to `true`. This will ensure that the container runs as a non-root user,  limiting the damage that could be caused by any potential attacks. By  adding a `securityContext` to the container in your Kubernetes pod, you can  help to ensure that your containerized applications are more secure and  less vulnerable to privilege escalation attacks.

cwe: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
metadata.license: Semgrep Rules License v1.0. For more details, visit semgrep.dev/legal/rules-license

extra.message: In Kubernetes, each pod runs in its own isolated environment with its own  set of security policies. However, certain container images may contain  `setuid` or `setgid` binaries that could allow an attacker to perform  privilege escalation and gain access to sensitive resources. To mitigate  this risk, it's recommended to add a `securityContext` to the container in  the pod, with the parameter `allowPrivilegeEscalation` set to `false`.  This will prevent the container from running any privileged processes and  limit the impact of any potential attacks.  In the container `insecure-app` this parameter is set to `true` which makes this container much more vulnerable to privelege escalation attacks.

Without this attribute, if an attacker can modify the externally hosted resource, this could lead to XSS and other types of attacks. rule yaml.github-actions.security.curl-eval.curl-eval: metavariable-pattern failed when parsing $SHELL's content as Bash: BRANCH="${{ steps.commit.outputs.branch }}"

# Create PR body
cat > pr_body.txt << 'PR_BODY'
## Weekly Security Tool Updates

This PR automatically updates all security tools to their latest versions.

### Verification

- All tools updated via `update_versions.py --update-all`
- Dockerfiles synced via `update_versions.py --sync`
- CI tests will verify compatibility

### Auto-Merge Policy

This PR will auto-merge if:
- D]F All CI tests pass
- D]F No conflicts with main branch
- D]F Version consistency check passes

---

R`eW **Automated PR** - Generated by weekly-tool-update workflow
R`TF **Schedule**: Every Sunday at 00:00 UTC
R`UX **Workflow**: `.github/workflows/weekly-tool-update.yml`
PR_BODY

# Create PR
gh pr create \
  --title "deps(tools): weekly auto-update $(date +%Y-%m-%d)" \
  --body-file pr_body.txt \
  --base main \
  --head "$BRANCH" \
  --label "dependencies" \
  --label "automated"

# Enable auto-merge
PR_NUMBER=$(gh pr view "$BRANCH" --json number --jq '.number')
gh pr merge "$PR_NUMBER" --auto --squash

# Initial wait (increased from 90s to 2 minutes)
echo "  Initial wait: 120s..."
sleep 120

# Retry loop with exponential backoff
MAX_RETRIES=5  # Increased from 3 to 5
RETRY_COUNT=0
SUCCESS=false

while [ $RETRY_COUNT -lt $MAX_RETRIES ]; do
  echo ""
  echo "R`UN Attempt $((RETRY_COUNT + 1))/$MAX_RETRIES: Verifying badges..."

  if bash scripts/dev/verify_badges.sh; then
    SUCCESS=true
    break
  fi

  RETRY_COUNT=$((RETRY_COUNT + 1))
  if [ $RETRY_COUNT -lt $MAX_RETRIES ]; then
    WAIT_TIME=$((60 * RETRY_COUNT))  # 60s, 120s, 180s, 240s exponential backoff
    echo "DPt Waiting ${WAIT_TIME}s before retry..."
    sleep $WAIT_TIME
  fi
done

if [ "$SUCCESS" = false ]; then
  echo ""
  echo "D[aQyP  Badge verification did not complete after $MAX_RETRIES attempts."
  echo ""
  echo "This is expected behavior and does NOT indicate a release failure."
  echo ""
  echo "Badges update asynchronously and typically take 5-30 minutes:"
  echo "  1. PyPI API propagation: 2-5 minutes"
  echo "  2. Badge CDN caching: 15-30 minutes for global propagation"
  echo ""
  echo "The release will proceed successfully. Badges will auto-update."
  echo ""
  echo "Manual verification (optional):"
  echo "  make verify-badges"
  echo ""
  echo "D]F Release workflow continues..."
  exit 0  # Exit with success to mark job as passed
fi

echo ""
echo "D]F Badge verification successful!"

Syntax error at line scripts/dev/update_tools.sh:17:
 `":$PATH:" in *":$HOME/.local/bin:"*) : ;; *) export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH" ;; esac

update_gitleaks() {
  log "Updating gitleaks"
  local TAG FILE URL ARCH
  ARCH=$(uname -m)
  TAG=$(curl -sSL https://api.github.com/repos/gitleaks/gitleaks/releases/latest | jq -r '.tag_name') || return 0
  FILE="gitleaks_${TAG#v}_linux_x64.tar.gz"
  [ "$ARCH" = "aarch64" ] || [ "$ARCH" = "arm64" ] && FILE="gitleaks_${TAG#v}_linux_arm64.tar.gz"
  URL="https://github.com/gitleaks/gitleaks/releases/download/${TAG}/$FILE"
  curl -fsSL "$URL" -o /tmp/gitleaks.tgz || {
    warn "download failed"
    return 0
  }
  tar -xzf /tmp/gitleaks.tgz -C /tmp gitleaks 2>/dev/null || true
  install -m 0755 /tmp/gitleaks "$HOME/.local/bin/gitleaks" 2>/dev/null || true
  ok "$(gitleaks version 2>/dev/null || echo gitleaks updated)"
}

update_trivy() {
  log "Updating trivy"
  local TAG FILE URL ARCH
  ARCH=$(uname -m)
  TAG=$(curl -sSL https://api.github.com/repos/aquasecurity/trivy/releases/latest | jq -r '.tag_name') || return 0
  FILE="trivy_${TAG#v}_Linux-64bit.tar.gz"
  [ "$ARCH" = "aarch64" ] || [ "$ARCH" = "arm64" ] && FILE="trivy_${TAG#v}_Linux-ARM64.tar.gz"
  URL="https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy/releases/download/${TAG}/$FILE"
  curl -fsSL "$URL" -o /tmp/trivy.tgz || {
    warn "download failed"
    return 0
  }
  tar -xzf /tmp/trivy.tgz -C /tmp trivy 2>/dev/null || true
  install -m 0755 /tmp/trivy "$HOME/.local/bin/trivy" 2>/dev/null || true
  ok "$(trivy --version 2>/dev/null | head -n1 || echo trivy updated)"
}
